metadata.description: Traditional Indian dishes with Singaporean influences, including North Indian, South Indian, and Muslim Indian styles

recipes.name: Mee Goreng
recipes.description: Stir-fried yellow noodles with eggs, prawns, tofu, and vegetables in a spicy, sweet sauce.
steps: Heat oil, fry garlic and chili paste until fragrant.
Add prawns and tofu, stir-fry until prawns turn pink.
Push to side, scramble egg, then mix in.
Add noodles, cabbage, bean sprouts, and sauces. Stir-fry until well combined.
Serve hot, garnished with green onions.
tips: Use sambal for extra heat.
Add potatoes for Indian-style mee goreng.
recipes.origin: Mee Goreng is a spicy fried noodle dish with Indian-Muslim roots, found at mamak stalls and hawker centres.

recipes.name: Fish Head Curry
recipes.description: Red snapper fish head simmered in a spicy, tangy curry with vegetables, a signature Singaporean-Indian dish.
steps: Heat oil, fry onions, garlic, ginger, and curry leaves until fragrant.
Add curry powder and chili paste, fry briefly.
Add fish head, eggplant, okra, and tomatoes. Stir to coat with spices.
Add coconut milk, tamarind paste, and salt. Simmer until fish is cooked and vegetables are tender.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh red snapper for best results.
Adjust tamarind for desired tanginess.
recipes.origin: Fish Head Curry is a uniquely Singaporean dish, blending South Indian and Chinese influences.

recipes.name: Curry Fish Head
recipes.description: Red snapper fish head simmered in a spicy, tangy curry with vegetables, a signature Singaporean-Indian dish.
steps: Heat oil, fry onions, garlic, ginger, and curry leaves until fragrant.
Add curry powder and chili paste, fry briefly.
Add fish head, eggplant, okra, and tomatoes. Stir to coat with spices.
Add coconut milk, tamarind paste, and salt. Simmer until fish is cooked and vegetables are tender.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh red snapper for best results.
Adjust tamarind for desired tanginess.
recipes.origin: Curry Fish Head is a uniquely Singaporean dish, blending South Indian and Chinese influences.

recipes.name: Arcot's Makkan Peda
recipes.description: Eurasian-Indian festive sweet of stuffed milk dumplings soaked in rose-scented syrup.
steps: Mix dough ingredients, knead until smooth. Divide and flatten, fill with nuts and raisins, seal into balls.
Deep-fry balls until golden. Simmer sugar and water to make syrup, add rose water.
Soak fried dumplings in syrup for at least 1 hour before serving.
tips: Use full-fat milk powder for richness.
Let dumplings soak thoroughly for best flavor.
recipes.origin: Makkan Peda is a festive sweet from Arcot, enjoyed by Singapore's Eurasian and Indian communities.

recipes.name: Soup Kambing
recipes.description: Spiced mutton soup with potatoes, carrots, and tomatoes, a South Indian-Muslim specialty.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add mutton, brown lightly, then add water and salt. Simmer 2–3 hours until meat is tender.
Add potatoes, carrots, and tomatoes. Simmer until vegetables are cooked. Serve hot.
tips: Use mutton with bone for richer flavor.
Serve with crusty bread or rice.
recipes.origin: Soup Kambing is a South Indian-Muslim mutton soup, popular at Indian Muslim stalls.

recipes.name: Soup Tulang
recipes.description: Spicy mutton bone marrow stew in a bright red, sweet-spicy sauce, a Singapore Indian-Muslim specialty.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add mutton bones, brown lightly, then add water, ketchup, sugar, and salt. Simmer 2–3 hours until meat is tender and sauce is thick and red.
Serve with bread to soak up the sauce.
tips: Use a straw to suck out the marrow.
Add more chili for extra heat.
recipes.origin: Soup Tulang is a Singapore Indian-Muslim creation, famous at Golden Mile Food Centre.

recipes.name: Chicken Briyani
recipes.description: Fragrant basmati rice cooked with spiced chicken, saffron, and ghee, a festive Indian-Muslim dish.

rice.saffron strands: a pinch, soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk

steps: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 1 hour.
Fry onions and whole spices in ghee until fragrant. Add marinated chicken, cook until just done.
Boil rice in salted water until 70% cooked. Drain.
Layer chicken and rice in a pot. Drizzle saffron milk, top with fried shallots and coriander.
Cover and cook on low heat (dum) for 30–40 minutes. Serve hot.
tips: Use good quality basmati rice for best results.
Let briyani rest 10 minutes before serving.
recipes.origin: A festive Indian-Muslim dish, popular at weddings and special occasions in Singapore.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: whole spices (cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, bay leaf)

recipes.name: Lamb Briyani
recipes.description: Fragrant basmati rice cooked with spiced lamb, saffron, and ghee, a festive Indian-Muslim dish.

rice.saffron strands: a pinch, soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk

steps: Marinate lamb with marinade ingredients for at least 1 hour.
Fry onions and whole spices in ghee until fragrant. Add marinated lamb, cook until just done.
Boil rice in salted water until 70% cooked. Drain.
Layer lamb and rice in a pot. Drizzle saffron milk, top with fried shallots and coriander.
Cover and cook on low heat (dum) for 45–60 minutes. Serve hot.
tips: Use good quality basmati rice for best results.
Let briyani rest 10 minutes before serving.
recipes.origin: A festive Indian-Muslim dish, popular at weddings and special occasions in Singapore.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: whole spices (cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, bay leaf)

recipes.name: Indian Rojak
recipes.description: Assorted fried fritters, potatoes, eggs, and vegetables served with spicy peanut sauce, a vibrant Indian-Muslim salad.
steps: Mix fritter ingredients, deep-fry spoonfuls until golden. Drain.
Arrange fritters, potatoes, eggs, cucumber, and tofu on a plate.
For sauce: fry chili paste, add peanuts, tamarind, sugar, and water. Simmer until thickened. Serve with salad.
tips: Add prawn fritters for extra flavor.
Serve sauce warm for best taste.
recipes.origin: Indian Rojak is a vibrant salad, popular at Indian-Muslim hawker stalls.

recipes.name: Butter Chicken (Murgh Makhani)
recipes.description: A North Indian favorite: tender chicken in a creamy, spiced tomato sauce. Served with naan or rice at Indian restaurants in Singapore.
preparation: Marinate chicken with yogurt, lemon, ginger-garlic, and spices for at least 2 hours.
Grill or pan-fry chicken until browned. Set aside.
Heat butter, fry onion, add tomato puree, cook 10 minutes. Add chicken, cream, and sugar. Simmer 15 minutes. Garnish with coriander.
tips: Marinate overnight for best flavor.
Add a pinch of kasuri methi (dried fenugreek) for aroma.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Marinate chicken with yogurt, lemon, ginger-garlic, and spices for at least 2 hours.
Grill or pan-fry chicken until browned. Set aside.
Heat butter, fry onion, add tomato puree, cook 10 minutes. Add chicken, cream, and sugar. Simmer 15 minutes. Garnish with coriander.

recipes.name: Chicken Tandoori
recipes.description: A classic North Indian grilled chicken, marinated in yogurt and spices, cooked in a tandoor or oven. Juicy, smoky, and deeply flavorful. Popular at Indian restaurants and mamak stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Score chicken pieces. Mix all marinade ingredients and coat chicken well. Marinate at least 4 hours or overnight.
Preheat oven or grill to high. Place chicken on rack and roast 30–40 minutes, turning once, until cooked and slightly charred.
Serve hot with lemon wedges and naan.
tips: Marinate overnight for best flavor.
Use a charcoal grill for authentic smokiness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Score chicken pieces. Mix all marinade ingredients and coat chicken well. Marinate at least 4 hours or overnight.
Preheat oven or grill to high. Place chicken on rack and roast 30–40 minutes, turning once, until cooked and slightly charred.
Serve hot with lemon wedges and naan.

recipes.name: Idli with Sambar
recipes.description: A South Indian breakfast staple: steamed rice cakes (idli) served with spicy lentil-vegetable stew (sambar). Popular at Indian restaurants and hawker stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek 4–6 hours. Grind to a smooth batter, ferment overnight. Add salt. Pour into greased molds, steam 10–12 minutes for idli.
Cook toor dal until soft. Fry mustard seeds, curry leaves, onion, and tomato. Add vegetables, sambar powder, turmeric, chili, and salt. Add dal, tamarind, simmer 15 minutes. Serve idli with sambar.
tips: Ferment batter in a warm place for best results.
Add ghee to sambar for extra aroma.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek 4–6 hours. Grind to a smooth batter, ferment overnight. Add salt. Pour into greased molds, steam 10–12 minutes for idli.
Cook toor dal until soft. Fry mustard seeds, curry leaves, onion, and tomato. Add vegetables, sambar powder, turmeric, chili, and salt. Add dal, tamarind, simmer 15 minutes. Serve idli with sambar.

recipes.name: Naan (Indian Leavened Flatbread)
recipes.description: A classic Indian leavened flatbread, soft and fluffy with a slight char, perfect for pairing with curries. Popular at Indian restaurants and mamak stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add yogurt and water to form a soft dough. Knead 10 minutes.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Divide into balls, roll out, and cook on a hot skillet or tandoor until puffed and charred. Brush with ghee. Serve hot.
tips: Add garlic or butter for variation.
Use a cast iron pan for best results if no tandoor.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add yogurt and water to form a soft dough. Knead 10 minutes.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Divide into balls, roll out, and cook on a hot skillet or tandoor until puffed and charred. Brush with ghee. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Palak Paneer
recipes.description: A North Indian vegetarian classic: paneer cubes simmered in a creamy spinach gravy. Served with naan or rice at Indian restaurants in Singapore.
preparation: Heat oil/ghee, fry cumin, onion, ginger-garlic, and chili. Add tomato, cook until soft. Add spinach puree, spices, and salt. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add paneer, cook 5 minutes. Stir in cream. Serve hot with naan or rice.
tips: Use fresh spinach for best flavor.
Add a squeeze of lemon for brightness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Heat oil/ghee, fry cumin, onion, ginger-garlic, and chili. Add tomato, cook until soft. Add spinach puree, spices, and salt. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add paneer, cook 5 minutes. Stir in cream. Serve hot with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Pani Puri
recipes.description: A popular Indian street snack: crisp puris filled with spicy, tangy water, potatoes, and chickpeas. Enjoyed at Indian restaurants and food stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Mix semolina, flour, baking soda, and water to form a stiff dough. Rest 30 minutes. Roll thin, cut circles, fry until puffed and crisp.
Blend mint, coriander, green chili, tamarind, cumin, black salt, chili powder, sugar, and water to make pani (spiced water).
Fill puris with potato, chickpeas, and pour in pani. Serve immediately.
tips: Serve puris fresh for maximum crispness.
Adjust pani spice and tang to taste.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Mix semolina, flour, baking soda, and water to form a stiff dough. Rest 30 minutes. Roll thin, cut circles, fry until puffed and crisp.
Blend mint, coriander, green chili, tamarind, cumin, black salt, chili powder, sugar, and water to make pani (spiced water).
Fill puris with potato, chickpeas, and pour in pani. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Samosa
recipes.description: A classic Indian snack: crisp pastry filled with spiced potatoes and peas, deep-fried until golden. Popular at Indian restaurants and snack stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Mix flour, salt, oil, and water to form a stiff dough. Rest 30 minutes.
Fry cumin seeds, onion, ginger, and chili. Add potatoes, peas, spices, and coriander. Cool filling.
Roll dough, cut into circles, fill with potato mixture, fold into triangles. Fry until golden.
tips: Seal edges well to prevent leaks.
Serve with mint or tamarind chutney.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian kitchens.
steps: Mix flour, salt, oil, and water to form a stiff dough. Rest 30 minutes.
Fry cumin seeds, onion, ginger, and chili. Add potatoes, peas, spices, and coriander. Cool filling.
Roll dough, cut into circles, fill with potato mixture, fold into triangles. Fry until golden.

recipes.name: Satti Sorru (Claypot Rice)
recipes.description: A South Indian specialty: rice cooked in a claypot with mutton, spices, and herbs. Fragrant, spicy, and deeply flavorful. Popular at Indian restaurants and food stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Heat oil, fry onion, ginger-garlic, and chili. Add mutton, brown well. Add tomato, spices, curry leaves, and salt. Add rice, coconut milk, and water. Cover and cook on low heat until rice and meat are tender. Serve hot.
tips: Use a heavy claypot for best results.
Add mint and coriander for extra aroma.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Heat oil, fry onion, ginger-garlic, and chili. Add mutton, brown well. Add tomato, spices, curry leaves, and salt. Add rice, coconut milk, and water. Cover and cook on low heat until rice and meat are tender. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Thosai (Dosa)
recipes.description: A classic South Indian crepe made from fermented rice and urad dal batter. Crispy, tangy, and served with chutney and sambar. Popular at Indian restaurants and hawker stalls in Singapore.
preparation: Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek 4–6 hours. Grind to a smooth batter, add water as needed. Ferment overnight.
Add salt. Heat a nonstick pan, pour batter, spread thin. Drizzle oil/ghee, cook until crisp. Serve with chutney and sambar.
tips: Ferment batter in a warm place for best results.
Add a little cooked rice for a softer texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek 4–6 hours. Grind to a smooth batter, add water as needed. Ferment overnight.
Add salt. Heat a nonstick pan, pour batter, spread thin. Drizzle oil/ghee, cook until crisp. Serve with chutney and sambar.

recipes.name: Dum Briyani (Biryani)
recipes.description: A festive Indian rice dish: fragrant basmati rice layered with spiced mutton or chicken, cooked on dum (sealed pot). Served at weddings, festivals, and Indian restaurants in Singapore.
preparation: Marinate meat with yogurt, ginger-garlic, spices, and salt for 2 hours. Fry onions until golden. Layer rice, meat, onions, mint, and coriander in a heavy pot. Drizzle saffron milk and ghee. Seal pot, cook on low heat 1 hour. Serve hot.
tips: Use a heavy-bottomed pot for even cooking.
Let biryani rest 10 minutes before serving.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
steps: Marinate meat with yogurt, ginger-garlic, spices, and salt for 2 hours. Fry onions until golden. Layer rice, meat, onions, mint, and coriander in a heavy pot. Drizzle saffron milk and ghee. Seal pot, cook on low heat 1 hour. Serve hot.
